key_points: Renowned author Joan Didion died at her Manhattan home at age 87.
The cause of death was complications from Parkinson’s disease.
Penguin Random House announced her passing, describing her as a trenchant writer and astute observer.
Didion was a leading figure in the 'New Journalism' of the 1960s and had a widely acclaimed career.
Her essay collections 'Slouching Toward Bethlehem' and 'The White Album' are considered modern classics.
Received the National Medal of Arts from President Barack Obama in 2013.
'The Year of Magical Thinking' won the National Book Award for Non-Fiction in 2005.
Collaborated with husband John Gregory Dunne on several screenplays, including 'Panic in Needle Park'.
Born in Sacramento in 1934; started her career with a Vogue magazine essay contest win.
A documentary about her life, 'Joan Didion: The Center Will Not Hold', was released in 2017.
spokespersons: Maria Shriver (Journalist and former California first lady)
